title.narrative: Increase accessibility to life-saving primary and secondary health services for the most vulnerable groups in Salqin, Idleb ,NW Syria.

description.narrative:
This project aims to increase accessibility to life-saving primary and secondary equitable health services to address the dire and immediate needs of health services for all age and sex groups boys, girls, women, and men, with attention to people with special needs physical disability, mental disorders, and psychosocial problems without any sexual discrimination, among IDPs and host communities in Salqin subdistrict in Harim, northwest Syria, which overwhelmed and crowded with new arrivals. The project will provide health services for 22325 beneficiaries (16745 IDPs and 5580 HC) (8280 women, 6020 boys, 6225girls, 1800 men) including all age groups children, adolescences, young adults, middle-aged adults, and older adults. The scope of interventions include: 1st: Support providing and expanding health services through Save the Soul hospital for child and maternity health, including the following services: 1. Reproductive health services BampCEmONC including IPD, OPD, ANC, PNC, Normal and C-section deliveries. 2. Gynecological services from the clinical services to surgical procedures. 3. Pediatric services including inpatient and outpatient care services. 4. Support the provision of essential medicines, medical supplies, and equipment for direct beneﬁciaries and the provision of reproductive health and safe delivery kit. 5. Providing treatment of chronic disease, noncommunicable diseases through the outpatient department.
2nd: Providing outreach health services to cover the most remote areas, camps, and areas most in need due to population density, new IDPs, lack of health services and health personnel working in the following communities in Salqin subdistrict (Saidiyeh , Ein Bikara, , Abu Talha, Delbiya, Tlul, Hir Jamus, Allani, Betiya, Tellemar, Kafr Hind) through: - Running two mobile clinics to provide outreach health activities to new and vulnerable IDPs in and out of camps. - Also, 2 CHWs teams will conduct household visits and provide services in accordance with the agreed standards developed by WHO (Family health, NCD, CD, Nutrition and healthy lifestyle), and to ensure an effective/selective referral pathways.
3rd: In addition, for more comprehensive responding to the needs for new and vulnerable IDPs, the services at facility and community levels will be integrated with Mental health and psychosocial support services as below: 1. Conduct awareness sessions about mental health issues for Community leaders and key individuals: teachers, imams, caregivers, and health staff. 2. Conduct awareness sessions about mental health issues in schools, clinics, and families to reach women, elderly and disabled people. 3. Providing focused non-specialized quality services, conduct individual and group counseling. 4. Identify cases that require medical care and refer them to the MHGAP trained doctor, in addition, if some cases they need other services, PSWs will refer them to the specialist. 5. Providing MhGAP interventions. Six PSSWs (4 providing services at community level, and 2 at health facility level), one PSS supervisor and one MHGAP doctor working in OPD will be allocated to provide MHPSS services for people in need.
From GBV and PSEA perspective, SDI will ensure the integration of GBV in Health services as there will be Women Waiting area within HF, ensure that SDI has available Females staff, SDI will train the staff on GBV and PSEA principles to strengthen their capacity to identify the GBV cases and refer it to GBV centers.
